resources.string: Accounting collects, analyzes, and reports financial data. It includes financial, managerial, and tax accounting. Financial accounting informs outsiders, managerial aids internal decisions, and tax accounting handles compliance.
The balance sheet captures a companys financial position, detailing assets, liabilities, and shareholders equity. It must always balance: Assets = Liabilities + Equity.
Assets are classified as current (convertible to cash within a year) or non-current (long-term). Examples include cash, inventory, and property.
Liabilities are classified as current (due within a year) or non-current (long-term). Examples include accounts payable, short-term borrowing, and long-term debt.
Shareholders equity includes common equity, preferred stock, treasury stock, and retained earnings. It represents owners claims on assets.
The income statement reports revenues and costs over a period, showing profitability. Key items include revenues, COGS, and net income.
Gross profit is revenues minus COGS. Operating expenses include SGA, depreciation, and RD, leading to operating profit (EBIT).
EBITDA adds depreciation and amortization back to EBIT. Net income is earnings after all expenses and taxes, crucial for profitability analysis.
The statement of cash flows tracks cash changes from operating, investing, and financing activities, explaining cash inflows and outflows.
Operating cash flows adjust net income for non-cash expenses and changes in working capital, showing cash generated from core operations.
Investing cash flows include cash spent on or received from the sale of long-term assets like property, equipment, and investments.
Financing cash flows involve raising or repaying capital through debt and equity, impacting long-term financial structure.
Analyzing financial statements involves assessing strategy, performance, and ratios. Key tools are comparative, common size, and ratio analysis.
ROE measures profitability by dividing net income by average shareholders equity. It shows how effectively equity is used to generate profit.
ROA divides net income by average total assets, indicating how efficiently assets generate profits.
Gross profit margin, the ratio of gross profit to revenue, shows how well a company manages direct costs of goods sold.
Operating profit margin (EBIT/revenue) indicates how well a company controls operating expenses relative to sales.
Pretax margin (EBT/revenue) and net profit margin (net income/revenue) measure profitability before and after taxes.
Liquidity ratios, like current and quick ratios, assess a companys ability to meet short-term obligations with available assets.
Solvency ratios, such as debt to equity and interest coverage, evaluate a companys ability to meet long-term debt commitments.
Activity ratios, including inventory turnover and receivables turnover, measure how efficiently a company manages its assets.
Valuation ratios, like P/E and P/B, compare market price to financial statement metrics, aiding in investment decisions.
Comparative analysis evaluates financial statements over time, identifying trends and changes in performance.
Common size analysis reports all items as percentages of revenues or assets, facilitating internal and cross-company comparisons.
Time-series analysis compares a firms financial data over multiple periods to identify growth patterns and trends.
Cross-sectional analysis compares financial data from multiple companies at the same point in time, highlighting relative performance.
Benchmark comparison uses industry norms to evaluate a companys performance, providing context for analysis.
Combining different ratios provides a comprehensive view of a companys financial health, aiding in strategic decision-making.
